Look, this is a really weird one, and my answer isn't a strict thumbs up/down affair.  If you were to take a statistical analysis of all the yes/no reasons I give you, they come up positive on the whole.  But whether YOU should get this game or not depends, ultimately, on how social you are.

I want to tell you about that, but I'm going to tell you about the game itself first so we can get that out of the way.  I want to give you a framework of context, because I am a generous soul.

You, and some arbitrary other number of players, are on a planet.  In 30 days, an asteroid is going to smack into the planet.  That's bad.  You collectively have 30 days to invent and implement sufficient technology to zap the asteroid away.  You'll do it in a Minecraft-y voxelly world, where you can dig up rocks, chop down trees, plant crops, hunt beasts for meat and skins, and so forth.  You'll build yourself a nice little home.

You will invent technologies to let you dig fancier rocks with better tools, plant and harvest more crops more efficiently, build better houses, process animal bits better, and so forth.  So nothing new there, right?

But the first catch with this game is a much closer eye towards realism.  Above all else, most every action you take consumes calories, and if you run out you can't do anything.  So you need to eat, and your diet needs to be well-balanced if you want to make the most of it.  You passively earn XP over time, and the rate of XP gain is based on your diet quality and the quality of your home.

Secondly, the state of all the critters is tracked, so if you extirpate all the capybaras or brown birds in one area, that's it.  They're extinct.  Trees take a few realtime days to grow back, and if you log an area to oblivion, you're out of wood.  Burning wood or coal or smelting metals releases pollution, and that air pollution is tracked.  The tailings (waste) from smelting has to be stored away somewhere or it will contaminate your water and kill off all the fish and make it hard to farm.  This stuff just doesn't go away.

Thirdly, ground takes up volume.  Yes, you can carry a lot as a player, but you need to empty your pockets on occasion.  Once you put rocks or dirt in a stockpile, it takes as much space as it did natively.  So waste management and landfills becomes kind of a big deal.

Your ability to build new tech is based on that XP gain, as I wrote above, and on a typical server, not one person can specialize in everything.  You need to do a lot of divide-and-conquer.  You'll need to... ugh, talk with the other players on your server.

But if you're not able to come to an agreement, you can set up a barter system.  Or even your own economy and monetary units.  Or contracts.

And so we have politics.  That's the real core of the game.  There's a whole legal system, where laws can be proposed, methods of enforcing or implementing those laws can be managed, leaders selected, and so forth.  The game runs a separate web server where you can log in to track these things.  Heavens, you can vote if you want.

So on a larger server, things could be run democratically.  The people may have collectively decided that a certain region of the planet is fit for strip mining, and pollution may only occur at Sunday between 12:00 and 12:15, or whatever.

Now, none of this spoke to me.  So when I played it, I nominated myself as the grand hierarch, the dictator that would make all laws and promptly effed off to play space golf.  The players made a kind of communistical collective and, after about six days, had had enough and went on to play other games.  I wound up saving our planet myself, though I made a hellblight of a continent in doing so.

So, in the end, here's your summary:  If you play this game with strangers, you're going to butt up against politics, weirdos with strange notions of "economies" and trying to find a useful niche for yourself so you can trade, like, artisanally-hewn rattan deck chairs for space pizza and plate glass windows.  And people who take politics seriously may be campaigning or otherwise annoying you.

If you play it with a few friends that you get along well with, the politics are virtually inconsequential and what you've got left is a bit of a shallow game that's slow to play.  It's basically a Minecraft-oid, but the house-building and farming never moved my wife that much.  She didn't find the house parts especially attractive, though it's a central part of the game itself.

And if you play it alone?  Umm, well, unless you tweak the server settings, you're going to be hampered a lot, and then it's just Minecraft with an awful lot of chores bolted on.  I tried it once, I wound up wizarding myself up a whack of stuff and amused myself for awhile by building a freeway a third of the way around the world before I stopped.

The game is harsh to novices. Despite a brief tutorial on basic survival, the game has such a large (and still growing) amount of game mechanics, meta layers and complexity, that it takes good 20-40 hours to just grasp the core principles. On the other hand, the game has no strict goal for an individual player. If you join a successful  server you might not need to do much besides doing menial labor of mining or chopping down trees to help stop the global meteor threat. And this combination leaves a broad space for replayability as in any given playthrough on a populated server you will only be able to do a tiny subset of professions, that are required for achieving the global goal. In that, I think that this is an almost perfect implementation of sandbox game concept.

However, keep in mind that this game is extremely biased towards social interactions and multiplayer. While you can technically play it solo or in a small group on a private server the world of ECO would feel dull and empty without the constant conflict of interests of different player groups. This game is definitely not for you if you want to just play something when you have 30 minutes of free time as on most occasions you will have to interact with other players and wait for them to react. Have you just set up a shop with freshly mined stone? Be prepared to wait for some hours of real time for someone to decide that your stone is a good deal for them and pick it up from your store. Do you dream of becoming a business owner and making a factory, that would employ half of the server's population? Same story here - the players who would do the work for you have their real life schedules and timezone differences, so do not expect things to start rolling the same moment you've placed the working party invitation. A typical work party completion time is 8-20 hours. Now, the game does good in providing tools such as contracts to make the interactions as asynchronous as possible, but interactions are mandatory and downtime for you is inevitable. Some work on these tools is still ongoing as the game is under heavy development in regards of meta layers such as global government system.

The social life also brings a lot of troubles with large organized groups of players having extreme power over the server's economics. The private servers are operating on "as is" basis and frequently lag, go offline or suffer from inadequate administration. This often results in servers dying out long before the meteor hits. Setting up a government and negotiating a global currency is almost a full-time diplomatic job intertwined with extreme amount of programming of laws using in-game law configuration language. 

However, if through all of these challenges you will manage to find a good server with a static group of core players who keep playing no matter what and good administration (have a look at the official White Tiger server if you are still looking), you will be rewarded with extreme amount of player-generated content such as:

- Organizing your own group of players, who would go together through many cycles, working your group's megafactory, that spits out high-tech products on the markets to build your economic domination over the rest of the server.
- Having lot's of fun, trying to survive the anarchy and political crysis periods as well as global sea level rise when your industry takes too much of the planets resources.

P.S. The last time I had so much fun from social interactions in an online game was when I discovered SS13.

Everything can go completely off the rails when you're playing with internet randos, but if you're able to get all those bodies to eek over the finish line before the month is up, there really is no more feeling more fulfilling. I can honestly say that of all my gaming experiences, 4 of the top 5 most satisfying occurred in this game.

So why the neg review? Because after uninstalling myself, I have come to realize that everything I said above no longer applies. Not because the game has inherently changed, but because the people playing it have become so utterly toxic.

Since this game occurs over a 30 day real-time stretch, you can imagine that some people get heavily invested... But I don't think outsiders realize just HOW invested the core players have become. I have seen everything from shouting matches to grown-ass adults crying. Literally, crying. These types of meltdowns can of course kill a run, and if everyone has spent weeks to get there, then losing out in the eleventh hour because the last smelter threw a tantrum really... just... sucks. 

And this is where the game has been worn into the ground. Not only are the Eco core that invested themselves, but they've become so jaded through so many failed runs that they've built up their own versions for how a run "should" be conducted to maximize your chances. Should a server not align with their vision, they will take their ball and go home. The more this game stagnates, the more ridiculous this behavior has become.

A perfect example of this came after the advent of the cost calculator plug-in. It is simple enough: you plug in the cost of basic resources and it'll calculate the total cost for all intermediates and final products, adjusted as tech progresses. When this was first produced, it made for a nice handy tool that players could use to help manage their shops. These days, it has been adopted as a cudgel by the Eco regulars. You just made a fancy sofa and put it on the market? You better have run it through a cost-calc because if you didn't and your server has 50 actives on it, then 10 of them will have run it through a spreadsheet, and they'll order you to change your price if it's different from theirs. Failure to comply will start with snarky comments, but will get more vitriolic from there. 

Oh, did you think this game involved you managing your own shop? Not anymore. Market inequities create production inefficiencies, which has the potential to kill a server long-term. Is any of this true? Not really, but the Price Gestapo *feels* like it might kill the server, so they'll quit preemptively if you don't adhere to their standards. 

Yes, this really happens... All. The. Time. Not even the official servers are spared this chicanery, and it is only one avenue that level-headed players have their own spent time held hostage.

From an administrative perspective, we've always had to balance server conditions / rules to woo the most players. This marries player needs as well, because they'll self-select into servers that have the best chances of succeeding, and those are the ones with the highest numbers. Common sense rules like "don't be racist or wall your neighbors in" just come with the territory of online gaming. 

However, that was years ago. If you want more than a dozen people today, you'd better set a pre-built government, mint a currency to start (fiat too), draw out the road districts, establish price control on starting goods, and install a dozen mods. Don't forget Big Shovel. If you forget Big Shovel, a flood of folks will demand it on Day 1 before rage-quitting. All of these steps almost guarantee a meteor win, but that is now the only path that the Eco community has been conditioned to accept. No challenge or risk, just a stale victory.

Meanwhile, the owners of these servers have only become more toxic themselves. They have developed their own script: micromanage all aspects of players' lives to ensure that it's impossible to fail. That drives the most numbers, after all. Don't expect to be able to run for office or build your own commune though. If one of these admins senses that the game is being played outside their control, they'll do whatever they can to shut you done, often using the thinnest veneer of justification to delete weeks' of your life.

A unique game where you pick a world at random and have a wonderful adventure is long since gone, replaced by a perpetual revolving door of tryhards bitterly complaining about prices and pollution, all under the thumb of control freaks drunk on their own power. Any attempt to adjust this dynamic will be met with derision. A distilled, uninteresting victory is better than none at all, and any who do not agree are to be shunned, shamed, or banned if necessary. The Devs are asleep at the wheel, convinced that this is all part of the plan as they roll out content at a snail's pace. 

All of this does nothing but drive people away. Returning players like myself can only stomach a couple weeks before disappearing for a year, and new players tend to bounce off in a day. Being berated about your price of nails is hardly a fun way to get introduced into a game.

And yet, if you ask these same core players what they think the future is for Eco, they'll gleefully launch into flights of fancy. This game's gilded age wasn't years ago, but just on the horizon. It really will be the next WoW killer. So long as everyone just listens to their ideas, we'll all be led to a promised land!

This might sound ridiculous from the outside, but you have to view this through the eyes of the Eco faithful. They've invested thousands of hours chasing the high of a successful run. They've seen the light! If only the rest of the world would do the same, it could be so much greater for us all. Never mind that most servers these days are indistinguishable from modded Minecraft. It has so much potential to be tapped!

At the time of this post, there is a 24 hour peak of 1600 people. A year before, it was 1700. A year from now, it'll be a 100 less, with the survivors even more unhinged than their predecessors. 

This environment will never get better, but it can keep getting worse. Can you still have lots of fun? Of course. But I wouldn't recommend trying. It really isn't worth the hassle anymore.

This game is quite ambitious. It has many of the features I'd hope to see in other multiplayer survival games for over a decade now - intricate cross-dependent crafting, land claim and management, dynamic world, dedicated professions. They even have several innovations in how they've designed a use of food to fuel calories that are spent as a currency/resource for the generation of labor in crafting benches. Interesting stuff!

Unfortunately, all of that dies in the minute-to-minute gameplay of the early game. In our small community of five players, we were blocked from early game goals by some sharp cross-dependencies. You need a butchery to cook food to advance cooking. Three different professions. The way skill progression is doled out, you each can only get one of those per real life 24-hour period at start. So, in the first 2-3 hours of play, you are blocked by the requirements from other skills.

What do you do instead?  Gather rocks. Cut trees. Gather rocks. Cut trees. Harvest plant fibers from weeds. THe same thing you do in ever other survival game, except here with costlier recipes, slower harvesting, and harsher weight management. Some of those features have interesting level ups. For example, you can only carry one chunk of dirt at a time to level or re-shape terrain. But if you have a carpenter make a cart, you can move lots more dirt. That advancement feels great. But it's one of the few actual early game wins that you feel. Advancement is trapped by incredibly grindy and slow work that leaves little reward.

When we saw this, our community (hosting a private server) did what we always do. We went to increase the rates on our server. Except there are only about six server settings . Documentation is lacking. The "official" wiki is out-of-date. It's nearly impossible to understand what the settings do. Even after we found out how to increase experience and skill gain, and gave the game another day, we were bored with the minute-to-minute play. Too little advancement early and it quickly became a calculation of DAYS of real play time to hit even mid-game goals.

Contrast this with a game like Satisfactory. Early game, you progress very rapidly through the goals of harvesting minerals, setting up basic automation, and unlocking new recipes. By mid-game, there are expensive tiers, but those are comprised of doing the early game stuff, except more and better. You always have interesting things to do and re-optimize in building and growth. 

Also - the world is round (cool) but locked to a size (uncool). Exploration as compared to a game like Minecraft, with infinite generation, is really low. This games does NOT scratch an exploration itch past the first few hours.

Eco is just harsh, grinding labor from the onset with hard blocks if you don't have a large community playing.

There's so much of this game that we would LOVE to love. But right now, I cannot recommend investing time in this game unless you don't mind very very heavy unmitigatable resource grind in the early game. 

What would make us give the game another shot?
* RE-worked early game with a lot more to do and lessened burden on cross-requirements
* Better player models / variety. The "undead stare" from the player models kills any desire to community build
* Some kind of more infinite world gen, or something that would make exploration more interesting
* Animal interaction / behavior needs to be less spastic. They are just everywhere, all the time, and feel more like clutter than anything I would want to conserve/preserve. We actually joked about deforesting the trees just to get rid of them

[h1]The Ecology of Insanity[/h1]
At 5 hours into this game, I told myself, "I can't wait to finish it at 200 hours and say 'no' on the review". At 147 hours in and walking away with catharsis I haven't felt in years, let's start.

Eco is a 3D game based around block/voxel dynamics, similar to the Minecraft-genre, focusing on resource collection, processing, and the building of structures and items. There's no combat, as it seeks to be a large, co-operative experience of players against an impending doom clock of a planet-killing meteor. The exact settings can change; I played on the default 30 day timer with a group of 3 regulars and 4 irregulars. That is 30 real days, not ingame.

There's a lot to unpack with this game. 

For one, the resource gathering and processing is simple and tedious to its core. I'm talking "Click to mine dirt, click to drop dirt, click to mine dirt, repeat 500 times for a basic road". Logistics is a valid concern at all steps as well. You must locate, build a transport route for carts/vehicles, acquire resources, process onsite or at a location, then if necessary, secondary or tertiary processing for a finalized product. As one goes up the tech tree, the more complex the intermediate steps become, but with the menial labor aspect of it constant and unchanging for the majority of the game. Repeat this for upwards of five or more resources, and you start to imagine some of the regular problems.

Eco is 'intended', or built towards, individual players specializing in certain job fields. This is as much an artificial limit as a pragmatic one--you only gain X amount of skill points over a time period of hours, then days and weeks. Now factor in doing the various, hours-long labors certain supply chains require. 'You' cannot do everything; a community of cooperative players is required. In this, Eco reveals its true MMO-like nature, and what everything else is bent toward servicing: social dynamics. 

With an actual in-game government, complete with constitution, political offices, currency minting, and all the trappings of real life, Eco gives you what you could experience by walking outside, from inside your house. By engaging with fellow players and navigating the bubble economy of fake money and personality, you can contribute toward the goal of winning the game, or suffering in some kind of simulated mirror of real life. The tagline 'a game based on the tragedy of the commons' is, at the heart, what Eco wants to be.

While the idea is intellectually interesting, the execution and pursuit of it is a willingness to self-inflicted calvinball that only a particular kind of player will desire. It could, arguably, serve as a 'life simulator' style game, with Minecraft-like principles bolted on top. But it does demand a large community of, probably, at least 20 or more players to truly thrive and explore these ideas. Small groups, or irregular players, will basically circumvent this design to play the actual game itself.

I do like some of their designs in actual gameplay. Linking work tables together, large self-working construction orders, transportation and stock management, are all done in a fairly sane and fun, at least initially, manner. The creation of your own workshop and providing for others is itself fun, but becoming a fake money wage slave is an inevitable fate. My small group resorted to communal behavior as a result, and the entire spectrum of government and civilization at large wasn't needed or used. Hence, our play experience is most likely very different from large servers.

I very notably only felt the game came alive for fun in building and doing work at the 'end game' tech tiers, where large construction options became available. Of the 147 hours we put in, we spent 20 hours in end-game before rushing for a win and escaping our unwitting bondage to Eco. If that sort of freedom and power had been available at the start, it would've been massively more fun. Not the banging rocks together and moving dirt--so much dirt--for literal hours every day just to have a house or mining quarry. I do not accept the 'recruit more people to move dirt for foundation/roading' as a fun incentive or good design, personally.

The game itself also suffers from serious performance problems, though that can eventually be resolved. The chief one is a recurrent memory leak that eventually nosedives framerate and performance into single digits. Frequent restarting of the client to experience regular performance, and then watch it die in front of our eyes, was a daily theme. Multiple different machines didn't report any success at even the lowest graphic settings.

The art style is itself simple and based on modern Earth principles; so what we know in this world we can expect to see in Eco's rendition. The music exists but I cannot think of anything that stood out to me. There's no story or anything, as any attempt at guidance is left to player tutorials. The UI is okay but seriously lacking in functionality that alleviate player tedium or storage management. What is there 'works', but I frequently wished for features the likes of Modded Minecraft consider standard. Shift+Click for instant movement from one inventory to another, for example, works in some screens and not others. Mass inventory movement doesn't exist and good heavens there is a lot of click+dragging. So much click+dragging.

Speaking of the environmentalism aspect of it: there isn't much, but that may change in the future. You largely have ground and air pollution, but only certain mid-to-late game facilities produce that stuff. You manage it by polluting and then stopping before global warming happens for the most part. Any semblance of healing or repairing nature, maintaining sanctuaries, etc, is just not there. The game seeks to punish you more for having to use industry to win than to create some kind of ecological balancing act. Frankly it is so forgettable otherwise I'm shocked it's as thin and vestigial of a feature as it is.


[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Eco is a very particular kind of game that masquerades under a skinsuit of another game. If you go into it for the 'environmentalist Minecraft' idea, it will quickly run into problems providing an experience. If you go into it looking for social communities, interactions, the drama thereof, built around the skeleton of a game, you can potentially get a lot more out of it. I am not kidding when I say this game works better with more players--the more there are, and the more regularly they play, the better this will side of it will perform. It is unironically an MMO-game in terms of its social commitment and requirements at such a scale.

Ultimately, my take away from Eco is that many of its ideas are neat, some of its executions are novel and improvements in the builder-resource genre, but it sacrifices too much upon the altar of social dynamics. Once a community agrees to an optimal form of resource flow toward progression and 'winning', the assumed interactivity it relies upon essentially vanishes. All that is left is resource gathering, transportation, processing, and then constructing buildings for our workshops/eventual death lasers. Considering how much of a slog that was, I cannot imagine it being any more enjoyable having to deal with people who may not, necessarily, want to work with me or be a good social experience in the first place.

Trying to imagine being actively sabotaged when creating progression-needed items/buildings about sucks the soul out of me, if I'm honest. 'Social pvp' has its place and perhaps I am not the sort of player Eco wants to invite in, ultimately.

Eco would have to do some serious revision to the core design of its existence before I'd ever feel comfortable recommending it. Frankly, more game based on ecology management and less social darwinism is my vote.

Eco is a Great game with some inherent flaws. 
It is a game about cooperation and working together to balance a world, stop a disaster and hopefully have fun. Soloing is harder but not impossible in some instances if the economy on the server is looked after and the people planning it are intelligent. If you like boundless, creativerse, minecraft etc you might like this, if you like the cooperative aspects of those titles.

A small map server or community is fun and I would highly recommend this game for a weekend lan party, with sped up skillpoint gain or a tight clan that play together.

A large map server or community suffers from some serious gameplay problems however, some people have talked about them in other reviews and I will try to cover all I have observed.

In a large world. Get there early, in the center of the city on day 1 and you'll always be far more priveledged than those that come later. I often find myself browsing the server lists looking for a new larger server starting for this very reason. For servers with crafting XP on, players who play more can maybe catchup, without crafting XP you're even more stuck. However crafting XP makes everyone a jack of all trades eventually and hurts the economy a bit more, it also vastly benefits those that play a lot of hours.

A certain amount of all this is logical if you think about the progression in other games. Here though, it's taken to the extreme. Players mint the currency, whoever does this and their friends are rich. On a large map location is everything, and whoever is closest to the center is in extremely advantageous position. Laws passed benefit cleaner technologies later on, whereas new players are still struggling and paying large bills from the laws to catch up. New players don't have the skill points to keep up with the demands of a end game economy, so they get stuck. Money gets in the hands of a few players, and new players struggle to get any.

All of this is reduced the smaller the player numbers and the smaller the map size, to be a non issue if you get to maybe 5 friends playing together, or a clan maybe, then it'd be a really fun game. As for solo play it is hard work, takes a long time, as eco takes a long time, it is a game about cooperation. That said for the die hard soloists they can enjoy themselves certainly, just expect a long game.

Now obviously the elephant in the room is that the admin can do anything he wants, it is his server, so finding a level headed fair admin who isn't too trigger happy is key. Finding one who will keep the peace, and the game world running, without cheating too much and not ticking the community off in the process. It is not a position for everyone certainly and some servers are going to be a nightmare because of this, while some a fun place to play.

In a game where the players can set laws on everything, the same applies. If you've got in an intelligent community who generally aren't jerks to each other, you'll probably have fun, if not the experience will suck.

I love Minecraft, but I have the same problem with it that I do with all pure sandbox games. I go into Minecraft with a goal in mind, something specific I want to build, and once it’s built, I’m done. I’m a goal-oriented gamer, and while I can come up with my own goals, my interest only lasts as long as those goals do. That’s why Eco seemed so interesting to me, being a very Minecrafty game with a very conspicuous goal. And it does both quite well, for as long as the ramshackle game built around it can hold up.

Eco places you on a lush little planet full of forests and oceans and teeming wildlife. Unfortunately there also happens to be a meteor in the sky that’s going to land rather destructively in 30 days. By cultivating the land, researching new technologies, and building your way from the stone age to modern times, you can save your tiny world from calamity. However, progress comes at the same price it does in the real world. Forests can be clear-cut to barren wastelands, furnaces can blacken the sky, and all your lovely wildlife can be hunted to extinction. There’s not much point to saving the world if you’re just going to destroy it yourself, so progress must be made carefully and responsibly if you’re going to succeed.

This real-world grounding is a cornerstone of Eco right out the gate. That 30-day countdown to the meteor impact is in real-time, for example. Thirty days after you start your world it will be devastated, so you’ll need to get right to work. The ecological simulation is detailed all the way down to soil viability for different crops, air pollution heat maps, and specific nutrition counts and costs for every food and action in the game. Do not let the blocky graphics fool you, because if you thought feeding yourself in Minecraft was a pain, Eco expects you to prepare a whole menu for yourself while monitoring your impact on the flora and fauna. There are a dizzying number of moving parts here, and while you don’t need to recognize them all to get started or even succeed this sort of detail is integral to the game experience.

Even the basic mechanics of felling trees and building structures are blown out into complex processes. If you want to build a log cabin, for example, you obviously need to chop down some trees. But when the trunk hits the ground it needs to be chopped into smaller logs that you can carry. These logs need to be carried to a crafting bench (or stockpile connected to a bench) and hewn into usable logs. These, at last, can be placed as blocks to build your home, except anything larger than a tool (like blocks or stones or logs) goes into a special holding slot that can only hold ten or so of that object. Extrapolate this out to the many kinds of bricks and tiles and materials that make up realistic-looking structures, and you can see how much more involved building a simple house is here than in comparable building games.

It’s all in the name of progress, though. Important stations for cooking or crafting or research must be placed in an appropriate room. Ultimately all the fiddly rules and crafting in Eco gives it a genuine purpose and a nod towards realism, something that loads of people have modded Minecraft heavily to achieve. Plus there are vehicles and complex machines to look forward to in the later stages of progress, along with some rather revolutionary ideas like a web-based law system that uses a basic scripting language to let you set laws for your world. You can also track economic exchanges once you develop money and the means to build little stores, so those with the patience to build up their society will find a very deep and detailed simulation to kick around in.

You can attempt to stave off the meteor yourself, but honestly Eco isn’t really designed with that in mind. Skill gains (for research and crafting) are scaled for a single player if you start an offline world, and with enough patience you can tech up on your own to victory. It’s just going to be a long, tedious road of swapping skill points around and building an entire compound of smelters and sawmills alone. Fortunately the game has a very active community right now, and players are quite welcoming and willing to help you understand what you should be doing. Many servers turn the meteor off entirely and set alternative goals for their worlds, so if you’d rather build a great society than battle a rock from space you have that option as well.

There’s a lot of promise in Eco already, and loads of systems to dig into and master, but not without their drawbacks. Like many Minecraft-ish projects this one is significantly unpolished, with long loading pauses and hitches when interacting with the world. New terrain is extremely slow to load so don’t expect any stunning vistas until you give the game a few moments to catch up to what you’re supposed to be seeing. There are plenty of conspicuous bugs too, like some spots where blocks won’t place properly and instead will stack infinitely on a pre-existing block. And despite the handy tutorial missions there are plenty of features that are never explained and must be sussed out on your own, like how to link storage to benches (which is essential for crafting with larger materials).

Eco is a rough product right now, but one with plenty of depth and opportunity for those willing to work for it. It’s very much a game made for folks who couldn’t enjoy Minecraft without mods, folks who needed that additional complexity and purpose to build with. If you’re not ready for that kind of commitment it might be better to wait this one out until the edges are all smoothed out, but there’s plenty to dig into now if you’re so inclined. With loads of features and technical options to developing your world, to say nothing of an actual purpose to your work, Eco is definitely one of the more promising sandbox builders out there.

Ever wonder what Minecraft would look like if Greenpeace made it?  Here is your game, Eco.  This game is a global voxel-based ecology simulator where, in its base form, players must use the land and resources to create a device to blow up an asteroid that will collide with your planet and destroy all life.  You start off as a player in a virgin world full of plants, animals, trees, oceans, and all of the beauty of nature, and you must take resources in order to accomplish the life-saving goal.  In doing so, however, players need to also be careful to not destroy the planet.  Everything, such as deforestation, pollution, and wildlife populations is interconnected and upsetting this balance too much to achieve your goal will destroy your world from ecological disaster.

And on this front the game provides amazing visual feedback.  Land becomes barren if you cut down too many trees.  Wildlife becomes sparse.  Wild foods will stop growing, water will turn muddy brown.  There are lots of signs that things are tipping in the wrong direction here.

In doing all of this, players also have individual wants and needs.  Food and housing are required to advance your character to the point where he can research and build these things, and players that have the better stuff will advance faster.  

Because of this, greed can set in very quickly and you can have a hierarchy develop, either through positive impacts like stronger leaders emerging, or negative impacts such as greed and corruption wanting some players to have a bigger slice of the pie.  To counter these impacts, players can vote on laws that prevent certain actions, such as cutting down too many trees, leaving trash around.  Or positive reinforcements such as rewards for good behavior like chopping tree stumps to allow new trees to grow in its place.

These are the mechanics of the game, but do they work?

This amount of collaboration sounds great, but it is a double edged sword.  When it works, it is one of the best and most fulfilling experiences there is.  When it doesn't work, it is a mess of trolls and me-players cutting down all of the trees, taking up all of the space, no roads, nothing.  Playing the game like this will exhaust resources extremely quickly, and joining in when the world has become a hell hole with no way to even make your place in it can be a miserable experience.  Latency is also an issue.  The game behaves incredibly poorly with high latency, even moreso than Minecraft or any other game.  Physics become bugged, you can teleport to different parts of the land without reason, and you're given no feedback.  The game will tell you when there are huge spikes, but it is a very negative experience when you end up on a bad server.

  In addition, it's very difficult to join in on games at later stages, beyond Day 10 perhaps (unless they are smaller servers).  Not all servers are newbie friendly as well, and while most people are welcoming to new players, there are ones that require high collaboration and won't welcome newbies, limiting your choices even more.

If you buy this game, buy it knowing that you might go on 5 straight servers that either are laggy or where the worlds are a mess, and that because of how hard it is to find a server.  You might even waste a couple hours on a server before you realize that you want no part of it.  If you do not have friends to play this, you'll have to be patient.  

I am going to continue recommending this game because of the effort from developers and the sky high fun factor when everything works.  It is an amazing educational experience, has parallels to real life, and you feel like a true part of the world you are in and a responsibility to do your part in maintaining balance between achieving your goals, those of the server, and not screwing up the planet while doing so.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Eco is a Dig, Craft, Build style of game which adds some new mechanics to the mix to create a fresh experience. The depth in this game is insane which allows player to put a lot of time into exploring the game’s systems. These complex systems also promote teamwork from players as they work to destroy a looming asteroid. The attention to detail and polish that this game already has shown me that the developers truly believe in their game. 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[u]Gameplay:[/u]
Eco follows the usual gameplay loop of a Dig, Craft, Build game in that a player collects resources to build items so that they can progress to the next tier. Unlike other games in the genre, Eco takes a new, realistic approach to survival.

When collecting large resources such as wood or rocks, a player must pick up the resources they have prepared for collection which fills their hands. This makes the player unable to perform tasks unless they drop the resources or store them at their base. By making resources more time consuming to acquire the player puts value into these resources, which is the theme of the game.

The player must be careful when collecting resources or using technology. Both of these actions can create pollution which in turn will make resources more difficult to collect. Entire species can go extinct. For example, when I joined a server I claimed a plot of land away from the rest of society. My base was next to another person’s base who hadn’t logged in in a while but had obviously been collecting resources. Wood drops trash branches around when a tree is felled and the entire biome was scattered with this garbage. This caused most of the biome to be devoid of food bearing plants and trees, making the game much harder. After I cleaned up the mess, the forest started to recover and trees were no longer as scarce. In Eco, it is only by living responsibly with the land that one can be successful. I thought that this is a unique concept that works very well when turned into a game.

What happens if one player wants to slowly destroy the plant around them despite the rest of the server wanting to live responsibly? That is where the law and government system comes in. Players are able to write laws which they then send into the government panel. Other players then vote democratically on the law. If the vote passes, the law effects the world. The law system is powerful and surprising customizable. It can even be used to enact server laws such as “Player who haven’t been on this server for more than 2 hours can’t create laws”.

Overall, this game is surprisingly fun and does a great job of teaching players about how ecosystems succeed or fail.

[u]Sound:[/u]
The sound in this game is great. Sounds represent the actions the player is performing crisply and believably. The workbench making noise constantly while working can be a little irritating, but I think it is trying to convey that progress is often a noisy event. The soundscape is beautiful and serene as the player can hear birds chirping and wind rustling through the trees. The sound design makes this a great relaxation game.

 [u]Music:[/u]
There is music but it is hard to notice as it blends well into the rest of the soundscape. The songs are relaxing and help the player get really immersed into the world. The music uses a lot of piano arrangements and will occasionally throw an different instrument into the mix.

 [u]Graphics:[/u]
The graphics are a minimalistic, polygonal style. The game does still have an element of its predecessor in it since it uses a cube style to portray the world. All of the visual are great and are easy to distinguish from one another. The menus can create a bit of clutter, but that is because the player will often look at many different menus such as the map and inventory simultaneously. 
 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Pros:[/u]
Fresh, New Mechanics
Great Immersion
Fun Gameplay
Nice Visual Style

[u]Cons:[/u]
Lots of Menus

[u]Rating[/u]
[b]9/10[/b]

Eco's government is sold as a high point but definitely one of the low points. On the server i played on there were several cases of laws... simply vanishing, with their effects not stopping with them. 

Besides that, the laws bely a very basic understanding of government. Making a law to stop something just literally stops you from doing it - just a popup saying "Wait, that's illegal!" You can literally just legislate away pollution - something anyone who's spent even a moment looking at any enviromental disaster would laugh at.

Eco also really fucks up if it wants you to simulate industrial development. There's no domestication of animals, and no trains, either - both major drivers of development. The major downside however is that the community in such a socially dependent game has to be really strong and aside from the bad apple in the bunch, Eco's community is split between what they want from the game which flows into the second and main point...

[h1] Eco's Identity [/h1]
I believe that Eco has some very creative and passionate devs with a vision of what they want the game to be and this vision is really unique and special. The problem is Eco's community creates a huge divide in this vision, they insist on pushing the game further and further towards being like any 'survival, basebuilding, minecraft clone' on steam. Eco from a game development standpoint is facing a lot of challenges that a casual member of the community doesn't understand, the first major one is this is actually a very niche game, it's 'minecraftiness' brings in a lot of new players who quickly realise its not minecraft and leave. The active player count in a game like this is vital to the experience, so when players expect all these different things that other games implement just fine, it actually ends up harming the game and the community.

Here's an example, mods. I love mods, I mod out nearly every game I play because it generally improves the experience. Eco has mods too, but eco also has a tiny playerbase that all want very different things.. So when there are 500 different servers and 80% of them are modded, it really splits up the playerbase all over the place and harms the experience of the game. In nearly any other game this wouldn't be a problem, there are plenty of server options, people can tailor their server however they like but what this game really needs is to reinforce one playstyle and design the game around that. 

The problems that this game faces are very core problems which need total mechanical changes, I think they're really moving in the right direction with upcoming releases that will have a hugely positive impact on the game. But the devs really need to just double down on their decisions and fulfill their vision of the game even if 'the community' doesn't like it.

Eco is not minecraft, eco is some entirely different beast that is really about humanity at its core. Players hate restrictions, they want freedom, they want to move fast and they love vanity, they don't realise that those restrictions are actually what make the game so rewarding. I guess what i'm saying is directly to the devs, believe in yourself, believe in your ideas, your vision for the game is sound and stop caving into player feedback that slowly destroys what makes eco special.

[h1] Now for my player feedback [/h1]
Please, please move development resources into the memory leak that has plagued our experiences forever. I love this game so I deal with it, but it probably turns away so many players. I love the entire idea of settlements and culture, I think this is going to be a huge move forward, it's super reassuring to see such a fundamental change even knowing the community will probably revolt at first.

Part of what really deters players from servers is the players who happily spend 10+ hours on the game every day and absolutely demolish other players. They are putting in more work, they should be rewarded more, but what actually happens is casual players have no chance and don't get to enjoy the game at all. I've played Eco for 725 hours over the past few years, so I think it's about time I reviewed it. Eco is a Minecraft-style game where you work together to destroy an asteroid due to impact in 30 (real) days, but all your activities (like cutting down trees, building factories, hunting for food) generate pollution, cause animals to go extinct and raise sea levels. The small, dedicated community is extremely passionate, and joining one of the official servers is a must, if only to experience what the developers intended the game to be (large communities with laws, elections, roles, economic competition and districts). I can still vividly remember the towns built on servers long dead, and the players who spent every waking minute building them.

That being said, I think what I am in love with is what the game COULD be. It has grand ambitions, and has already delivered a few of those ideas, but it still falls short. It COULD be this great cooperative experience of working together to advance, but not destroy the planet in the process. It COULD be a great societal simulator where laws and elections are satisfying and meaningful. It COULD be a challenging balance where it's easy to permanently disrupt the ecosystem to a point of no return.

However, there's a few things holding the game back from really being a success outside it's small, dedicated player base. Firstly, it needs lots of balancing - the asteroid is FAR too easy to destroy (usually destroyed at about 10-11 days into a server), making it a complete non-threat. The game also HEAVILY favours players who join in the first few hours of a new server and dominate a particular skill tree by playing for 14+ hours a day in the first week. And the pollution caused by industry activities is so localised, and weak, that in all my time in this game over the past few years I've NEVER seen the sea levels rise (and that's meant to be one of the worse consequences).

Secondly, the UI is still difficult to learn, despite many improvements over the past few releases (including tutorials), particularly the whole laws/elections/voting interface. This has the effect of most players (except for a dedicated few) not getting too involved in debating or writing laws, or voting in elections (in a server of around 100 active players, it would be typical for less than a dozen to be ACTIVELY involved in debating or writing laws).

Finally, maybe due to the above issues or maybe just life, most players will play heavily for the first few days of a new server and then never log on again. For a game built around depending on each other and cooperating, this can be incredibly frustrating when a player who makes something you need disappears. It creates a cycle of:

[list]
    [*]Search for and join a server less than 1 day old
    [*]Play like crazy for a few days, have loads of fun
    [*]Can't move to the next skill ladder into player X makes something
    [*]Player X hasn't logged on for a couple of days
    [*]Only log on to keep your store updated and/or projects going, while waiting for player X
    [*]Log on to a completely dead server, decide it's not going to happen
    [*]Search for and join a server less than 1 day old
[/list]

All in all, the game has SO MUCH potential, and I look forward to future releases if these things are addressed. In summary, I would recommend this game if it was on sale, and you had a group of friends to play with who were equally patient or forgiving of the balancing issues I mention above.

I've sunk about 30 hours into one single player game and what I've found is that the game is filled by nature with tedious mechanics. I find the grind somewhat enjoyable, but it is reasonable to understand why someone would be turned off from it when the game requires you to spend dozens of hours just moving material. 

This problem is mitigated to an extent with multiplayer. There the focus is on creating a community that leans on each other, as each person is restricted to being a specialist in just a few fields. The idea is that you will produce goods for other players to purchase from your store and use as they see fit, be it creating more specialized goods or improving their houses. Multiplayer is clearly the ideal way to play the game in my opinion, however it also comes with the anxieties associated with actual commerce as supply and demand is important to remain wealthy enough to remain a factor in the development of the game. 

Specialties are tied to various books that when right clicked produce scrolls, these scrolls in turn enlighten the user to a new specialty allowing them to take on a new field. Most specialties have a clear flow. For instance you have a [Logging] specialty. It allows you to cut down trees more efficiently both in calories spent and the amount of chops. You can then take [Hewing] which allows you to turn the logs you've chopped into building components, which, as you gain more skill, reduces the cost of the recipe both in time and materials. Specialties also have recipes that require either the knowledge of them or having spent a specialty point on them. In single player you receive specialty points at an accelerated rate, where as in multiplayer you receive them at a normalized rate. This encourages trade and having a focus on a particular set of specialties in multiplayer.

Multiplayer also has an interesting mechanic in that there are server wide laws and the ability to denote a universal currency. Some instances I've seen is a tax on cutting down trees, which you can recoup the cost of by clearing the resulting trunk and debris. These mechanics also lend themselves to abuse. Part of the game is balancing industry and progress versus the environmental impact of needing to rip up plants, slaughtering animals, chopping forest, and so on. There are byproducts produced by some crafting, in particular smelting, that are direct poisons to the environment if not handled correctly. I've read stories of servers where someone gets into control of the mint, over printing currency and controlling the market, then there is the instances of people just lightly hiding previously mentioned byproducts in holes around the world, killing it slowly. 

If you made it this far, you might wonder, what is the goal of the game. Its simple, stop a meteor that will annihilate your world in a set amount of days using lasers. Straight forward as far as goals go, but in order to get those lasers, you'll have to go from sticks and stones to iron tools and brick buildings, then even further to modern construction equipment such as excavators and bull dozers to acquire enough materials to both build and power these laser arrays. All of these goals are acheived in realtime. Thankfully it can be sped up in singleplayer, but in multiplayer it is likely disabled.

Tl;dr: Game is fun, but grindy. Play in multiplayer if you want a fuller experience. Games take 14+ real life days.

Hello Jaxyl,
thank you for your honest review :)

The time based leveling has been toned down at the last rework of the skill system to only make the general progress tied to time (but still being very influencable with food and housing), while the actual progress in your profession is tied to doing stuff related to that profession.

We do not plan to change this as this is a method of ensuring that players do not skill too far ahead on servers, which is one of the biggest issues in Eco currently, which you probably have already read in many other reviews that talk about exactly that. Removing the time limitations would make single players on servers totally unable to compete at any level, not providing for a pleasant play experience.

Nontheless, servers can configure the skill gain and the same can be done for singleplayer. We do offer multiplicators for the speed of your skill gain, the experience cost of skills as well as for the speed of leveling up in specialties and the crafting cost and crafting time of recipes. We do also offer some basic defaults for specific numbers of players, but fine-tuning those depending on the playstyle of the audience of the server (or yourself for singleplayer) is always a good idea.

In regards to the endgame we lately announced Eco Infinite which will be a long-term development focus, we will still refine and polish existing features, but there will now be a big focus on making Eco viable for longer term play, which is another issue that many players have outlined in reviews and on our channels. We deem it important to tackle that issue as it is relevant to the vast majority of the players and hence very important.

It is correct the game does not currently have water physics, mostly because those are always a more sophisticated part of development and also for the fact there is no inherent requirement for it currently. Water physics, at least very basic ones, is something we want to look at later down the road and might play a bigger role as soon as we introduced boats. For irrigiation you can use aqueducts, by the way, those are made with brick stones.

While I do understand the temptation to shape the world as you would like it, for example by re-routing rivers, that is a very minor part of what Eco is about. We feel like tackling a major issue with longetivity that affects everyone is something we need to do with priority.
